revision.text:
{{Infobox medical condition | Name = Adenomatoid odontogenic tumor | Image =Adenomatoid odontogenic tumor.jpg | Caption = | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = | ICD9 = | ICDO = M9300/0 | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeshID = }} The '''adenomatoid odontogenic tumor''' is an odontogenic [[tumor]]<ref name="pmid16429194">{{cite journal |vauthors =Nigam S, Gupta SK, Chaturvedi KU |title=Adenomatoid odontogenic tumor - a rare cause of jaw swelling |journal=Braz Dent J |volume=16 |issue=3 |pages=251–3 |year=2005 |pmid=16429194 |doi= 10.1590/S0103-64402005000300015|url=http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0103-64402005000300015&lng=en&nrm=iso&tlng=en}}</ref> arising from the [[enamel organ]] or [[dental lamina]].
==Epidemiology== It is fairly uncommon, but It is seen more in young people. Two thirds of the cases are found in females.<ref name="urlOdontogenic tumors">{{cite web |url=http://www.dental.washington.edu/case_of_month/dec08/tumors.html |title=Odontogenic tumors |work= |accessdate=2009-01-04}}</ref>
==Presentation and diagnosis== Two thirds of cases are located in the anterior [[maxilla]], and one third are present in the anterior [[mandible]].<ref name="pmid17505612">{{cite journal |vauthors =Nonaka CF, de Souza LB, Quinderé LB |title=Adenomatoid odontogenic tumour associated with dentigerous cyst--unusual case report |journal=Rev Bras Otorrinolaringol (Engl Ed) |volume=73 |issue=1 |pages=129–31 |year=2007 |pmid=17505612 |doi= |url=http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0034-72992007000100022&lng=en&nrm=iso&tlng=en}}</ref>
Two thirds of the cases are associated with an impacted tooth (usually being the [[Canine tooth|canine]]).
On [[radiograph]]s, the adenomatoid odontogenic tumor presents as a radiolucency (dark area) around an unerupted tooth extending past the [[cementoenamel junction]].
It should be differentially diagnosed from a dentigerous cyst and the main difference is that the radiolucency in case of AOT extends apically beyond the cementoenamel junction.
[[Radiograph]]s will exhibit faint flecks of radiopacities surrounded by a radiolucent zone.
It is sometimes misdiagnosed as a [[cyst]].<ref name="pmid16270916">{{cite journal |vauthors =Handschel JG, Depprich RA, Zimmermann AC, Braunstein S, Kübler NR |title=Adenomatoid odontogenic tumor of the mandible: review of the literature and report of a rare case |journal=Head Face Med |volume=1 |issue= |pages=3 |date=August 2005|pmid=16270916 |pmc=1266042 |doi=10.1186/1746-160X-1-3 |url=http://www.head-face-med.com/content/1//3}}</ref>
==Treatment== Treatment can involve [[enucleation (surgery)|enucleation]].<ref name="pmid18568215">{{cite journal |vauthors =Vasconcelos BC, Frota R, Cardoso AB, Porto GG, Carneiro SC |title=Adenomatoid odontogenic tumor |journal=Braz J Otorhinolaryngol |volume=74 |issue=2 |pages=315 |year=2008 |pmid=18568215 |doi= |url=http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0034-72992008000200026&lng=en&nrm=iso&tlng=en}}</ref>
